Award.AwardTitle: Variability of wind effects on natural ventilation and pollutant transport in buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605091
Lo, Liang Chung J.

With expanding energy consciousness in the building sector, architects and engineers have been increasingly using natural ventilation as a means to reduce energy expenditures. While natural ventilation has been used for thousands of years in various culture worldwide, the current modern method of designing for natural ventilation is simplistic and assumes steady flow, thus misestimating actual natural ventilation rates and their associated energy and indoor air quality impacts. The key reason behind such difficulty is the inherent unsteadiness of the wind in both its direction and magnitude. Unlike mechanical ventilation, which is driven by fans with well-tuned control, the wind's effect on ventilation is wholly unpredictable given the current approach. Such lack of knowledge may result in unintended consequences in energy consumption, human comfort, and even the overall health and wellbeing of the occupants. To better understand the consequences on building airflow and occupants of wind variability, this research project will analyze quantitatively, for different building forms and locales, the impacts of wind-driven natural ventilation flow in terms of ventilation effectiveness, energy consequences, and indoor air quality.

These goals of the research project will be accomplished by: 1) Researching the ideal formulation of a probabilistic transient wind effect framework that describes wind's variable impacts on buildings, as well as researching what minimum time scale that metric should operate on; 2) Simulating wind-building interactions in the nine National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) established climate zones in the contiguous United States for a selections of building types from Department of Energy's representative building stock in the U.S., using both computational fluid dynamics (CFD) methods and quasi-steady state approximations; 3) Investigating a broad spectrum of factors of the impact of the framework, such as ventilation effectiveness, energy impacts, and indoor air quality and occupant productivity and health. The research is anticipated to impact the building design process by allowing engineers to properly design for the wind harnessing potential, rather than considering natural ventilation solutions as an afterthought as in most existing building designs. This improvement would result in more energy efficient buildings, higher occupant productivity, and lower absenteeism rates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural ventilation in the building is been receiving more and more attention from researchers, policymakers as well as broad citizens, especially during the challenging period of pandemic which ventilation is one of the key preventive measures. Even though the benefits of applying natural ventilation into building design are obvious, huge complexity and difficulties are involved while designing naturally ventilated buildings to quantify the amount of air that can be introduced. The reason for these difficulties is contributed by the unsteady characteristics of the natural wind.

This project has demonstrated three different advances which can be applied to better assess wind-induced ventilation as well as understanding wind-building interaction. The first advance is the use of statistical wave function investigation often used in signal processing to study wind characteristics. The second advance is the development of a CFD based automated simulation tool that can investigate many scenarios without manual intervention. The third advance is the application of machine learning (via artificial neural network models) in ventilation airflow rate approximation.

This project has provided us with better knowledge and tools to further understand how wind interact with buildings and strengthen our ability to assess health and risks in our built environment. The more accurate ventilation rate can also help the improvement of our current building energy simulation which only supports crude wind-induce effects in its current state.
